folder: State Street & Whitehall Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
State Street, east from (No. 7) a point between Pearl and Whitehall Streets and towards the latter, showing mainly the Home for Irish Immigrant Girls at No. 7. View No. 2 shows this detail solely.

J. J. Corell
P. L. Sperr Collection    View 1: 1900

Beecher Ogden    View 2: 1937

folder: State Street & Whitehall Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) 7 State Street, north side, between Whitehall and Pearl Streets, showing the Home for Irish Immigrant Girls, as seen from Battery Park.

About 1905.

Brown Brothers.

(2) The same, showing a close view of the stairway and entrance.

About 1911.

(3) The same as No. 1 at a later date. Also shown is No. 6, the 6-story house adjoining it, after improvement.

September 25, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: State Street & Whitehall Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
1 to 6 State Street, (left), at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Whitehall Street, showing the Seamen's Church Institute (No. 1, corner building) and contiguous to it the house of the British Consulate General (No. 2). Also seen, are Nos. 46 to 34 Whitehall Street (right), west side, north from and including State, to Pearl Streets. Nos. 1 to 3 State and 46 to 40 Whitehall Streets, were demolished in 1913, and their sites are now (1937), occupied by the 12-story South Ferry Building. Nos. 4-5 (white house) and 6, upon which two additional stories were added, now comprise a 6-story annex to South Ferry Building.

1907.

Brown Brothers.

folder: State Street & Whitehall Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
1 to 6 State Street, (left), at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Whitehall Street, showing the Seamen's Church Institute (No. 1, corner building) and contiguous to it the house of the British Consulate General (No. 2). Also seen, are Nos. 46 to 34 Whitehall Street, (right), west side, north from and including State to Pearl Streets. Nos. 1 to 3 State and 46 to 40 Whitehall Streets, were demolished in 1913 and this site is now (1937) occupied the 12-story South Ferry Building. Nos. 4 and 5 (white house) and 6, upon which two additional stories were added, now comprise a 6-story annex to the South Ferry Building. 1907.

Brown Brothers.

folder: State Street & Whitehall Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
No's 1 to 5 State Street, at adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Whitehall Street (right). Upon the latter thoroughfare appears a view to Pearl Street. The corner buildings comprising No's 1 to 3 State Street and 40 to 46 Whitehall Street were demolished in 1913. Upon this site was erected the 12-story South Ferry Building.

No. 1 is occupied by the Seamen's Church Institute; No. 2, the British Consulate General and No. 4, the Deutsches Lutheran Emigraten Haus (German Lutheran Emigrant House).

1912

Gift of Urbrock Collection
H. N. Tieman Company
REPRODUCTION RIGHTS QUESTIONABLE

folder: State Street & Whitehall Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
7 State Street, north side, between Whitehall and Pearl Streets, showing the Mission of Our Lady of the Rosary, and the Home for Irish Immigrant Girls. This building was erected prior to 1800 and came into the possession of Moses Rogers about that time. William Bayard owned same subsequently. For a short while it was the property of Robert P. Getty, who became the first Mayor of Yonkers. Other occupants were, A. Gardener, and G. Howland (in 1830) after which it was used by the Federal Government during the Civil War for military purposes. The Pilot Commission were the last occupants prior to the purchase by the present tenants in 1885. A legend infers that the low brick addition back of the Mission is the oldest slave building left. A descriptive account will be found in the column "About New York" by Meyer Berger. This appeared in the New York Times of April 22, 1940.

About 1912

H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

folder: State Street & Whitehall Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
1 to 8 State Street (right to left) at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Whitehall Street, showing prominently the House for Irish Immigrant Girls. (Mission of Our Lady of the Rosary) at No. 7.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

No 7 State Street was erected prior to 1800 and came into the possession of Moses Rogers about that time. William Bayard owned same subsequently. For a short while it was the property of Robert P. Getty, who became the first Mayor of Yonkers. Other occupants were A. Gardener, and G. Howland (in 1830), after which it was used by the Federal Gov't. during the Civil War for military purposes. The Pilot Commission were the last occupants prior to the purchase by the present tenants in 1885. A legend infers that the low brick addition back of the Mission is the oldest slave building left. A descriptive account will be found in the column, "About New York" by Meyer Berger. This appeared in the New York Times of April 22, 1940.

folder: State Street & Whitehall Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Bowling Green, south side, between State (right) and Whitehall (left) Streets. Building shown, is the U.S. Custom House; the front of which as shown, occupies the sites of Nos. 1-7 Bowling Green; former 4 1/2 story buildings, known as 'Steamship Row.'

January 14, 1932.

International News Photos.

folder: White Street & State Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Whitehall Street, at State Street and viewing westward along the latter, showing a W.P.A. track removal project. On the left is a portion of Battery Park.

September 14, 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

folder: White Street & State Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Whitehall Street, south from State Street, showing W.P.A. employees removing street car tracks under the elevated line, at South Ferry.

September 14, 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

folder: White Street & State Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Whitehall Street, west side, north from State Street to Bowling Green and showing across the latter point a portion of the Cunard Building. Preceding same is the ornate Custom House.

September 14, 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

folder: South Ferry & State Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
South Ferry: Details of the "El" station, showing in No. 1, the 6th and 9th Avenue tracks and in No. 2, the 2nd and 3rd Avenue portions. To the left of the first view is a portion of Battery Park. The buildings shown face on State Street. Those in the second photo front on Whitehall Street.

June 7, 1940
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan: South Ferry - State Street
